values.description:
This is highly inspired on SASC rounds, which live in cloudsim-widgets:

#!/osrf/cloudsim-widgets/src/a0b023501934088e6e642ca6f8a6988129ea2df6/server/sasc/rounds.js?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default

The objective of having SRC rounds on this server is to minimize the amount of logic which must be handled by the browser. On SASC, the browser is responsible for keeping round data in sync with simulator data. Having this on the portal means that the same `csgrant`  can handle simulators, sshkeys and rounds, so there's less round trips to the browser, the site runs faster, and we have less chances of missing data (like orphan machines which happen often on SASC).

Note that VPN keys still live on the cloudsim-keys server. It would be interesting for this server talk directly to cloudsim-keys to relieve even further the burden on the browser.

This is meant to be non-intrusive, so once SRC is over, we can just remove a couple files.

This is just a suggestion of how we could do it, there are still many holes to be filled, which I marked with TODOs. Feel free to propose a complete redesign.

This pull request adds:

* POST, DELETE and GET routes to create a new SRC round
* Didn't add a PUT route for now because I think it would be nice if we could live without one. That is, all data is generated the moment the round is created, and destroyed when it is deleted. I think this would affect mainly machine state updates, but I might be missing something here.
* Added swagger for convenience (go to /api)
* Added tests
values.title: Beginning of SRC rounds

summary.raw:
This is highly inspired on SASC rounds, which live in cloudsim-widgets:

#!/osrf/cloudsim-widgets/src/a0b023501934088e6e642ca6f8a6988129ea2df6/server/sasc/rounds.js?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default

The objective of having SRC rounds on this server is to minimize the amount of logic which must be handled by the browser. On SASC, the browser is responsible for keeping round data in sync with simulator data. Having this on the portal means that the same `csgrant`  can handle simulators, sshkeys and rounds, so there's less round trips to the browser, the site runs faster, and we have less chances of missing data (like orphan machines which happen often on SASC).

Note that VPN keys still live on the cloudsim-keys server. It would be interesting for this server talk directly to cloudsim-keys to relieve even further the burden on the browser.

This is meant to be non-intrusive, so once SRC is over, we can just remove a couple files.

This is just a suggestion of how we could do it, there are still many holes to be filled, which I marked with TODOs. Feel free to propose a complete redesign.

This pull request adds:

* POST, DELETE and GET routes to create a new SRC round
* Didn't add a PUT route for now because I think it would be nice if we could live without one. That is, all data is generated the moment the round is created, and destroyed when it is deleted. I think this would affect mainly machine state updates, but I might be missing something here.
* Added swagger for convenience (go to /api)
* Added tests
summary.html:
This is highly inspired on SASC rounds, which live in cloudsim-widgets:

#!/osrf/cloudsim-widgets/src/a0b023501934088e6e642ca6f8a6988129ea2df6/server/sasc/rounds.js?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default

The objective of having SRC rounds on this server is to minimize the amount of logic which must be handled by the browser. On SASC, the browser is responsible for keeping round data in sync with simulator data. Having this on the portal means that the same csgrant can handle simulators, sshkeys and rounds, so there's less round trips to the browser, the site runs faster, and we have less chances of missing data (like orphan machines which happen often on SASC).

Note that VPN keys still live on the cloudsim-keys server. It would be interesting for this server talk directly to cloudsim-keys to relieve even further the burden on the browser.

This is meant to be non-intrusive, so once SRC is over, we can just remove a couple files.

This is just a suggestion of how we could do it, there are still many holes to be filled, which I marked with TODOs. Feel free to propose a complete redesign.

This pull request adds:

  • POST, DELETE and GET routes to create a new SRC round
  • Didn't add a PUT route for now because I think it would be nice if we could live without one. That is, all data is generated the moment the round is created, and destroyed when it is deleted. I think this would affect mainly machine state updates, but I might be missing something here.
  • Added swagger for convenience (go to /api)
  • Added tests

values.description:
~~This builds on top of pull request #55, please review and merge that first~~

At the moment, it's the client's responsibility to pass the machine type when requesting the start of a round. There are a few problems with this:

* Competitors can start rounds with any machine type, even if it has nothing to do with the competition
* Machine types are hardcoded on the widgets, so updating the ami means redeploying the website (as we do for SASC)

This pull request makes it so:

1. There are two "official" machine types in the portal, named `src-simulator` and `src-fieldcomputer`.
1. The official machine types must be manually created by an admin and shared (read only) with all 20 teams. Creation and sharing happens only once for the whole competition.
1. When teams start a round, the official machines are used
1. When an admin starts a round, they can optionally specify a custom machine type to override the official ones.
1. Changing the official machine types can be done through the `PUT /machinetypes/<type>` route. ~~(it should be easy to create a widget for it)~~ [Using this widget](#!/osrf/cloudsim-widgets/pull-requests/143/machine-types-widget/diff)
values.title: Use machine types for SRC

summary.raw:
~~This builds on top of pull request #55, please review and merge that first~~

At the moment, it's the client's responsibility to pass the machine type when requesting the start of a round. There are a few problems with this:

* Competitors can start rounds with any machine type, even if it has nothing to do with the competition
* Machine types are hardcoded on the widgets, so updating the ami means redeploying the website (as we do for SASC)

This pull request makes it so:

1. There are two "official" machine types in the portal, named `src-simulator` and `src-fieldcomputer`.
1. The official machine types must be manually created by an admin and shared (read only) with all 20 teams. Creation and sharing happens only once for the whole competition.
1. When teams start a round, the official machines are used
1. When an admin starts a round, they can optionally specify a custom machine type to override the official ones.
1. Changing the official machine types can be done through the `PUT /machinetypes/<type>` route. ~~(it should be easy to create a widget for it)~~ [Using this widget](#!/osrf/cloudsim-widgets/pull-requests/143/machine-types-widget/diff)
summary.html:
This builds on top of pull request #55, please review and merge that first

At the moment, it's the client's responsibility to pass the machine type when requesting the start of a round. There are a few problems with this:

  • Competitors can start rounds with any machine type, even if it has nothing to do with the competition
  • Machine types are hardcoded on the widgets, so updating the ami means redeploying the website (as we do for SASC)

This pull request makes it so:

  1. There are two "official" machine types in the portal, named src-simulator and src-fieldcomputer.
  2. The official machine types must be manually created by an admin and shared (read only) with all 20 teams. Creation and sharing happens only once for the whole competition.
  3. When teams start a round, the official machines are used
  4. When an admin starts a round, they can optionally specify a custom machine type to override the official ones.
  5. Changing the official machine types can be done through the PUT /machinetypes/<type> route. (it should be easy to create a widget for it) Using this widget

values.description:
When a round is created:

- a simulator instance and a field computer instance are launched

- ssh keys for these instances are created and permissions are set depending on the mode it's in (practice vs competition)

- server vpn keys are generated by posting to the keys server

- the cloudsim.options data will be populated with ssh key url and vpn config settings once all necessary info is available (after ~10seconds when simulator ip is available).

- the round data will be populated with ssh key and instance data
values.title: Create SRC rounds with keys and appropriate permissions

summary.raw:
When a round is created:

- a simulator instance and a field computer instance are launched

- ssh keys for these instances are created and permissions are set depending on the mode it's in (practice vs competition)

- server vpn keys are generated by posting to the keys server

- the cloudsim.options data will be populated with ssh key url and vpn config settings once all necessary info is available (after ~10seconds when simulator ip is available).

- the round data will be populated with ssh key and instance data
summary.html:
When a round is created:

  • a simulator instance and a field computer instance are launched

  • ssh keys for these instances are created and permissions are set depending on the mode it's in (practice vs competition)

  • server vpn keys are generated by posting to the keys server

  • the cloudsim.options data will be populated with ssh key url and vpn config settings once all necessary info is available (after ~10seconds when simulator ip is available).

  • the round data will be populated with ssh key and instance data

values.title: Add route for src simulation data

summary.html:
The simulation instance will perform PUTs to this route to update data such as score, time left, etc.

The should be able to pack arbitrary data (with all fields, not partially filled) into the body, e.g. 

{
    "rounds": [{
        "id": 1,
        "score": 3
    }, {
        "id": 2,
        "score": 0
    }],
    "time_left": 700
}

the browser should then be able to get data updates through websockets

values.description: Currently ssh key pairs on AWS are named sshkey-xxx. The problem is that AWS key generation service is shared by dev and production servers across all projects so the names eventually collide and result in AWS key generation errors. So give them unique names

values.description:
add a route that acts as a proxy to the sim instances

Any posts to the sim instances can be done through this route by adding a `host` and `path` params, e.g. `host: '12.34.56.78'`, `path: '/simulations'`, `cmd: 'ls -la'`

summary.html:
add a route that acts as a proxy to the sim instances

Any posts to the sim instances can be done through this route by adding a host and path params, e.g. host: '12.34.56.78', path: '/simulations', cmd: 'ls -la'

values.description:
This PR updates in the DB the correct simulator resource with the updated termination_date and the aws_termination_time (when set).

It also updates the updateInstanceStatus method to manually set a termination_date, when a status difference is found between simulator resources and aws information.

summary.raw:
This PR updates in the DB the correct simulator resource with the updated termination_date and the aws_termination_time (when set).

It also updates the updateInstanceStatus method to manually set a termination_date, when a status difference is found between simulator resources and aws information.
summary.html:
This PR updates in the DB the correct simulator resource with the updated termination_date and the aws_termination_time (when set).

It also updates the updateInstanceStatus method to manually set a termination_date, when a status difference is found between simulator resources and aws information.

values.description:
This PR updates SRC rounds logic to send the team's s3 keys to the simulator instance when launching a round. The keys are sent as part of options.json.

When no keys are found, then "undefined" is sent in options.json. This is done this way to allow bash scripts to always have a value to compare against (the entry will always exist in options.json).
values.title: Send configured S3 keys to options.json when launching a simulator instance

summary.raw:
This PR updates SRC rounds logic to send the team's s3 keys to the simulator instance when launching a round. The keys are sent as part of options.json.

When no keys are found, then "undefined" is sent in options.json. This is done this way to allow bash scripts to always have a value to compare against (the entry will always exist in options.json).
summary.html:
This PR updates SRC rounds logic to send the team's s3 keys to the simulator instance when launching a round. The keys are sent as part of options.json.

When no keys are found, then "undefined" is sent in options.json. This is done this way to allow bash scripts to always have a value to compare against (the entry will always exist in options.json).

values.description:
This PR addresses [this comment](#!/osrf/cloudsim-widgets/pull-requests/166/set-and-update-user-budget/diff#comment-37094797) on a PR from the `cloudsim-widgets` repository.

Upon posting a new metrics config, an optional `admin_identity` can be passed. If it exists, it gives read/write permissions to it. This is used to grant permission to the `src-admins` identity upon creation, and avoid depending on callbacks to grant that permission.

A new test case was included, to see if the resource is created and the permissions are correctly set. The previous creation test was modified to check that this field does not exists.

ptal @preyna , @chapulina
fyi @andres_fortier
values.title: Grant permission to optional Admin Identity upon metric creation.

Upon posting a new metrics config, an optional `admin_identity` can be passed. If it exists, it gives read/write permissions to it. This is used to grant permission to the `src-admins` identity upon creation, and avoid depending on callbacks to grant that permission.

A new test case was included, to see if the resource is created and the permissions are correctly set. The previous creation test was modified to check that this field does not exists.

values.description:
Instead of deleting the `srcround` resource, it sets the `public.terminated` field to true. 

Also added a `practice` field to `srcround` and `srcsimulation` resources so we know which ones belong to the finals. Based on this information, we should be able to easily identify srcsimulation resources for the finals
values.title: Mark SRC rounds as terminated instead of deleting them

summary.raw:
Instead of deleting the `srcround` resource, it sets the `public.terminated` field to true. 

Also added a `practice` field to `srcround` and `srcsimulation` resources so we know which ones belong to the finals. Based on this information, we should be able to easily identify srcsimulation resources for the finals
summary.html:
Instead of deleting the srcround resource, it sets the public.terminated field to true.

Also added a practice field to srcround and srcsimulation resources so we know which ones belong to the finals. Based on this information, we should be able to easily identify srcsimulation resources for the finals

values.description:
turns out we'only retrying for (10*1000ms) 10 seconds to get ip from AWS.  So altogether 20 seconds (initial delay of 10s + retry of 10s) is probably not enough..? 

So updated to retry for 200 * 5s = 1000s, hopefully that's sufficient.
values.title: Increase get instance ip timeout

summary.raw:
turns out we'only retrying for (10*1000ms) 10 seconds to get ip from AWS.  So altogether 20 seconds (initial delay of 10s + retry of 10s) is probably not enough..? 

So updated to retry for 200 * 5s = 1000s, hopefully that's sufficient.
summary.html:
turns out we'only retrying for (10*1000ms) 10 seconds to get ip from AWS. So altogether 20 seconds (initial delay of 10s + retry of 10s) is probably not enough..?

So updated to retry for 200 * 5s = 1000s, hopefully that's sufficient.

values.description:
otherwise we get these errors:

~~~
_http_outgoing.js:549
    throw new TypeError('first argument must be a string or Buffer');
    ^

TypeError: first argument must be a string or Buffer
    at ServerResponse.OutgoingMessage.end (_http_outgoing.js:549:11)
    at Request.<anonymous> (/var/app/current/server/src/proxy.js:21:13)
    at emitOne (events.js:82:20)
    at Request.emit (events.js:169:7)
    at Request.onRequestError (/var/app/current/node_modules/request/request.js:884:8)
    at emitOne (events.js:77:13)
    at ClientRequest.emit (events.js:169:7)
    at Socket.socketErrorListener (_http_client.js:267:9)
    at emitOne (events.js:77:13)
    at Socket.emit (events.js:169:7)
~~~
values.title: Prevent portal from crashing due to bad proxy requests

summary.raw:
otherwise we get these errors:

~~~
_http_outgoing.js:549
    throw new TypeError('first argument must be a string or Buffer');
    ^

TypeError: first argument must be a string or Buffer
    at ServerResponse.OutgoingMessage.end (_http_outgoing.js:549:11)
    at Request.<anonymous> (/var/app/current/server/src/proxy.js:21:13)
    at emitOne (events.js:82:20)
    at Request.emit (events.js:169:7)
    at Request.onRequestError (/var/app/current/node_modules/request/request.js:884:8)
    at emitOne (events.js:77:13)
    at ClientRequest.emit (events.js:169:7)
    at Socket.socketErrorListener (_http_client.js:267:9)
    at emitOne (events.js:77:13)
    at Socket.emit (events.js:169:7)
~~~
summary.html:
otherwise we get these errors:

_http_outgoing.js:549
    throw new TypeError('first argument must be a string or Buffer');
    ^
